title: Dias
common: The surname Dias does not have a singular origin; it stems from a patronymic, signifying "Diego's son" or "Diogo's son". Furthermore, an additional complexity arises: when indigenous individuals converted to Christianity, they often adopted the surname Dias as well. This multifaceted nature led Américo de Moura to enumerate 10 distinct Dias families (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 345-348). However, documents published years later revealed that some of these families were interrelated (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23).

families.name: Dias (São Vicente)
history: Family of Lopo Dias and Beatriz Dias.

people.name: Lopo Dias
history: Lopo Dias resided in Santo André between 1555 and 1558 (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 346). By 1562, he had relocated to São Paulo (Atas de São Paulo, Volume I, pp. 17). He lived a long life, surviving even beyond the passing of his son in 1609 (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113).

Throughout this documentation, he is consistently referred to by the surname Dias, as that was the name he used in all his official records (Atas de São Paulo, Volume I, pp. 17, 19, 39, 91, 93, 105, 108,109, 344, 345). However, it's worth noting that there's a possibility he also went by the surname Machado, as evidenced by his brother, Rui Dias Machado, mentioned in the canonization document of Priest Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23). In modern times, we tend to use all surnames, but historical practices varied significantly. The Portuguese culture did not have criteria well established during centuries (Monteiro, Nuno G., 2008 ; Gonçalves, Iria.).

Another notable aspect of Lopo Dias' life was his association with the Christian faith. He was among the citizens who signed to build the city's church (Atas de São Paulo, Volume I, pp. 344, 345), and in his later years, he was affiliated with the "Ordem Carmelita" (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 133, 141-142; Castro Coelho, H. V., 1994, pp. 111).

José G. Salvador speculate that Lopo Dias may have been of Jewish descent, citing "O apelido, lobo, era adotado por muitos que descendiam da tribo de Benjamin" [the surname, "lobo", was used by many descendants of Benjamin tribe] (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 132, 197), it's worth considering other historical contexts. The Qasi family, for instance, included individuals named Lobo/Lubb, tracing back to Visigothic and Islamic roots (Flórez, Henriques, 1756, p. 488; Crônica de Afonso III, pp. 9,16 ; Banu Qasi, History Tracers). Additionally, the suggestion of a homonymous "Lopo Dias" who was Jewish (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 132, 197) lacks concrete primary sources, especially considering the diversity within the Dias and Machado families (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23). The whole hypothesis does not have a unique primary source supporting it, and it looks like there is a connection with a partial primary source (Torre do Tombo, Mesa da Consciência e Ordens, Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66; Bogaciovas, Marcelo M. A, 2015, pp. 279-280) that is cited without to explicit the issue to be partial, it is also appended an additional novel that there were a lawfare in another religious habilitation "falcatruas que se processou na habilitação do homônimo" [lawfare happened during homonymous diligences] (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 31, 32). Claims based on partial primary sources should be approached with caution, as demonstrated in a case related to Pedro Dias Paes, son of Garcia Roiz Paes, where defamation occurred during conflicts between the Pires and Camargo families, highlighting the complexities of historical interpretation and the need for rigorous scrutiny (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 28, 47, 48, 66-69).

marriages.name: Beatriz Dias
history: Suzana Dias is referenced in the canonization documents of Priest José de Anchieta, cited for her daughter (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23), and mentioned in her son's inventory (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113).

While there is certainty regarding her marriage, evidenced by declarations from her children, her parentage remains uncertain. Therefore, I'll present two possibilities. Initially, she is considered a potential daughter of Tibiriçá (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 443; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume IX, pp. 67).

marriages.name: Beatriz Dias
history: Alternatively, she might be the daughter of João Ramalho (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 443; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 34), with Silva Leme naming her Beatriz Ramalho in this hypothesis (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 34). However, it's worth noting that João Ramalho did not mention any Beatriz Ramalho in his testament (W. Luiz, 1904, pp. 564).

children.name: Suzana Dias
history: According to priest José de Anchieta's canonization documents (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 35).

children.name: Belchior Carneiro
history: According to his own words (Inventários e Testamento 2, 1920, pp. 113; Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume I, pp. 34).

people.name: Suzana Dias
history: According to her testament, Suzana married twice and had 17 children, all from her first marriage to Manuel Fernandes Ramos (Inventários e Testamento 33, 1946, pp. 12,13).
She was also a witness to the canonization of Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 23).

Of particular interest is Suzana Dias' relationship with indigenous people: her inventory reveals that she granted freedom to one indigenous individual, while also allocating others to her sons (Inventários e Testamento 33, 1946, pp. 13,14). Additionally, during wartime, André Fernandes enlisted indigenous individuals from Francisco Camargo (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 94). This occurred despite their shared indigenous ancestry (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 443).

A preliminary, ongoing study indicates that Suzana Dias' mitochondrial haplogroup is C1b (subgroup) (de Sillos, Luiz Gustavo, 2023, t. 01:07:10), although further research is needed to finalize these findings.

marriages.name: Manoel Fernandes Ramos
history: According her own words (Inventários e Testamento 33, 1946, pp. 12,13).

families.name: Dias (Cachoeira do Campo)
history: This family traces its roots back to Bento Dias, who resided as an 'aggregated' individual in the household of Anna Theodora Pinto in Cachoeira do Campo, Minas Gerais (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1824, Fogos 10).

people.name: Bento Dias
history:
Gathering detailed information about him proved challenging; however, the available data are gleaned from population maps, revealing:
  • In 1824, Bento Dias was noted as an 'aggregated' individual in Anna Theodora Pinto's residence (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1824, Fogos 10).
  • By 1831, he had entered into marriage with Anastácia and was residing on the land of Maria Úrsula da Silva, who granted freedom to Anastácia (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1831, Fogos 22). Following a change in residence, Bento Dias adopted the surname Silva.
  • In 1838, Bento and his wife had established their own household ('Fogo'). Interestingly, Bento's recorded age appears incorrect, as he is only one year older than his wife, whereas previous population maps indicated a five-year difference. Anastácia's age, however, is accurately represented (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1838, Fogos 83), although she altered her surname in this particular population map.

marriages.name: Anastasia
history: According to population map (Arquivo Público Mineiro, 1838, Fogos 83).

children.name: João Anastácio Dias
history: According to his baptism (Paróquia Nossa Senhora de Nazaré, 1847.)

families.name: Dias (Indígena - Bahia)
history: Throughout centuries, and even today, there exists a widespread desire among people to trace their ancestry back to specific groups in order to avoid mixing of ethnicities (Schneider, Alberto L., 2016, pp. 99, 100). As a result of these desires, some historical narratives have been rewritten, posing a challenge for proposals such as the one put forward by Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 03). However, recent research has reshaped our understanding of what truly transpired.

people.name: Pedro Dias
history: Américo de Moura reports that Pedro Taques documented a marriage between a Portuguese man named Pedro Dias and an indigenous woman named Maria da Grã (de Moura, Américo, 1951, pp. 347). This account is echoed by another genealogist, Luiz G. Silva Leme, who states that "Pedro Dias, da família — Parente Dias Velho —, de Portugal, veio a São Vicente como irmão leigo da Companhia de Jesus" [Pedro Dias, from Family - Parente Dias Velho -, of Portugal, came to São Vicente as a lay brother of the Society of Jesus] (Silva Leme, Luiz G., 1904, Volume VII, pp. 03). However, Priest Serafim Leite, in his work "História da Companhia de Jesus" mentions that "Em 1566, estava na Baia, o Irmão Pedro Dias, ainda noviço, nascido aqui na terra" [In 1566, Brother Pedro Dias was in Bahia, still a novice, born here in the land] (Projeto Compartilhar, "Pedro Dias"), suggesting that the notion of his marriage to an indigenous woman may be a fictionalized account.
Another proposal, more consistent with possible historical facts, was presented by H. V. Castro Coelho (Projeto Compartilhar, "Pedro Dias").
In this section, we treat only the novice.

marriages.name: Terebé/Maria da Grã
history: A hypothesis that became part of a fictional narrative according to Priest Serafim Leite (Projeto Compartilhar, "Pedro Dias").

families.name: Dias - Índigenas (Espírito Santo - Fundão)
history: In the 8th edition of the Genea magazine published in 2020, researcher/genealogist Gilber Rubim Rangel presented data on the "devassa" carried out by the Jesuits (Rangel, Gilber R., 2020, pp. 75-116), and among the individuals listed, there are indigenous people with the surname Dias.

people.name: Jerônimo Dias
history: He was killed in prison (Rangel, Gilber R., 2020, pp. 96).
